column1: The band I'm in has been rehearsing daily because we have a concert in two weeks.
A sentence fragment is a group of words that does not express a complete thought.
Rehearsing daily because we have a concert in two weeks.
This fragment is missing a subject. It doesn't tell who is rehearsing.
The band I'm in.
This fragment is missing a verb. It doesn't tell what the band I'm in is doing.

This fragment is missing an independent clause. It doesn't tell what happened because of the concert."	"This is a sentence fragment. It does not express a complete thought.

column2: approximately eight hundred million pounds of rock were removed from the mountain to create the monument."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The original text is indeed a sentence fragment because it lacks a main verb and does not complete a thought. It starts with a prepositional phrase ""During the construction of Mount Rushmore
column2: but does not have an independent clause to provide context or meaning. The suggested revision corrects this by adding a verb (""were removed"") and creating a complete thought
column3: thus transforming the fragment into a full sentence."

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.

column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with black eyes or red eyes

column3: which is for red eyes
column4: is dominant over the e allele
column5: which is for black eyes.

column1: Black eyes is the recessive allele's version of the eye color trait. A koi fish with the recessive version of the eye color trait must have only recessive alleles for the eye color gene. So
column2: offspring with black eyes must have the genotype ee.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype ee.
Red eyes is the dominant allele's version of the eye color trait. A koi fish with the dominant version of the eye color trait must have at least one dominant allele for the eye color gene. So
column2: offspring with red eyes must have the genotype EE or Ee.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype EE or Ee.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with black eyes to offspring with red eyes is 4:0. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will always produce offspring with black eyes. This cross is expected to never produce offspring with red eyes."	"ANSWER: 4:0

column5: the ratio of black-eyed to red-eyed offspring is 4:0

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Did you really vote for Richard as class treasurer? Didn't you hear that his uncle was imprisoned for embezzling $1.5 million?"	['circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself'
column2: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Richard can't be trusted with money, because his uncle embezzled money. However, even though his uncle couldn't be trusted with money, that doesn't necessarily mean that Richard can't be trusted with it. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The argument presented in the text employs the logical fallacy of guilt by association. It attempts to discredit Richard's ability to serve as class treasurer based on the actions of his uncle
column2: implying that Richard is untrustworthy because of his uncle's criminal behavior. This reasoning is flawed
column3: as it does not provide any evidence of Richard's character or capabilities
column4: but rather makes an unjust connection between him and his uncle's misconduct."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
cooking a pancake
rust forming on a bicycle frame"	['Both are caused by heating.'
column2: 'Both are caused by cooling.'
column3: 'Both are only physical changes.'
column4: 'Both are chemical changes.']	3		closed choice	grade4	natural science	chemistry	Physical and chemical change	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it re­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Cooking a pancake is a chemical change. Pancakes are made from pancake batter. A cooked pancake is a different type of matter than pancake batter. Pancake batter is wet and slippery. Cooked pancakes are fluffy and can be good to eat!

Rust forming on a bicycle frame is a chemical change. Oxygen in the air reacts with iron in the bicycle frame. The outside of the frame turns into a different type of matter called rust. Rust is reddish-brown and falls apart easily.
Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Cooking is caused by heating. But rust forming on a bicycle frame is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 3
SOLUTION: Both cooking a pancake and rust forming on a bicycle frame are examples of chemical changes
column2: where the original substances undergo a transformation to create new substances with different properties. Cooking a pancake transforms the batter into a fluffy
column3: edible product
column4: while rust formation alters iron into a reddish-brown compound that is structurally different from the original metal. Hence
column5: the commonality between these two changes is that they both involve chemical reactions."

column3: puzzle
column4: propose
column5: and answer.

column1: A sequential structure describes a series of events that happens in a certain order. This structure often uses specific dates and times or words such as first
column2: next
column3: during
column4: finally
column5: and while."	The text uses a problem-solution structure to show how architect I.M. Pei modernized the Louvre with an entrance that complemented the existing building. In the text

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column3: 'circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself']	0		closed choice	grade7	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Mariana must be a reckless driver, because her brother is a reckless driver. However, even though Mariana's brother is reckless, that doesn't necessarily mean that Mariana is, too. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text presents an argument that discredits Mariana based on her brother's behavior
column2: suggesting that her association with him makes her a reckless driver as well. This exemplifies the logical fallacy known as guilt by association
column3: where the negative traits of one person are unfairly attributed to another solely based on their relationship. The reasoning fails to establish a direct link between Mariana's driving abilities and her brother's actions."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=705x411 at 0x312CAA180>	Which of these continents does the equator intersect?	['North America'
column2: 'Australia'
column3: 'Africa']	2		closed choice	grade4	social science	geography	Maps	Use lines of latitude and longitude	"Lines of latitude and lines of longitude are imaginary lines drawn on some globes and maps. They can help you find places on globes and maps.

column1: Lines of latitude show how far north or south a place is. We use units called degrees to describe how far a place is from the equator. The equator is the line located at 0° latitude. We start counting degrees from there.
Lines north of the equator are labeled N for north. Lines south of the equator are labeled S for south. Lines of latitude are also called parallels because each line is parallel to the equator.

Lines of longitude are also called meridians. They show how far east or west a place is. We use degrees to help describe how far a place is from the prime meridian. The prime meridian is the line located at 0° longitude. Lines west of the prime meridian are labeled W. Lines east of the prime meridian are labeled E. Meridians meet at the north and south poles.
The equator goes all the way around the earth

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=243x241 at 0x312D531D0>	What is the expected ratio of offspring with fuzzy leaves to offspring with smooth leaves? Choose the most likely ratio.	['0:4'

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with fuzzy leaves or smooth leaves
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the leaf texture trait. The question tells you that the L allele
column3: which is for fuzzy leaves
column4: is dominant over the l allele
column5: which is for smooth leaves.

column1: Fuzzy leaves is the dominant allele's version of the leaf texture trait. A summer squash plant with the dominant version of the leaf texture trait must have at least one dominant allele for the leaf texture gene. So
column2: offspring with fuzzy leaves must have the genotype LL or Ll.

column1: There are 2 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype LL or Ll. These boxes are highlighted below.

Smooth leaves is the recessive allele's version of the leaf texture trait. A summer squash plant with the recessive version of the leaf texture trait must have only recessive alleles for the leaf texture gene. So
column2: offspring with smooth leaves must have the genotype ll.

column1: There are 2 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype ll. These boxes are highlighted below.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with fuzzy leaves to offspring with smooth leaves is 2:2. This means that
column3: on average

column3: while only offspring with the genotype ll will have smooth leaves. In this case
column4: there are equal numbers of boxes representing each phenotype in the Punnett square

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
I don't trust Professor Chang's findings. Another researcher at her university was caught falsifying data. So
column2: it's likely Professor Chang has
column3: too."	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column4: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something'
column5: 'bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct']"	1		closed choice	grade10	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Professor Chang's research is untrustworthy because someone else at her university was caught falsifying data. However, this isn't necessarily true. The practices of one researcher at a university do not necessarily reflect the practices of another researcher at the same university. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text exemplifies the guilt by association fallacy
column2: as it discredits Professor Chang's findings based solely on the actions of another researcher at her university. This reasoning is flawed because it unjustly links the integrity of one researcher to another without any direct evidence or correlation between their work. The argument implies that because one person acted unethically
column3: others in the same environment are also likely to do so
column4: which is not a valid conclusion."

column1: In a chemical change

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns

column1: A poem rhymes when it has a pattern of words that end in the same sound.

Internal rhyme is when at least one of the rhyming words appears inside the poem's lines.

—From William Blake

column1: The amount of gravitational potential energy stored between an object and Earth depends on the mass of the object. The amount of gravitational potential energy also depends on the distance between the object and the center of Earth. This distance increases when the object moves higher and decreases when the object moves lower.

decreases | decreases

column4: the potential energy also decreases. Therefore
column5: since the water balloon was moving closer to the Earth
column6: the gravitational potential energy stored between the water balloon and the Earth decreased."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
A rainbow appeared in the sky the day before basketball tryouts
column2: and I made the team! If there's a rainbow when I try out in the spring
column3: I'm sure I'll make the team again."	"[""ad hominem: a personal attack against one's opponent""
column4: 'false causation: the assumption that because two things happened together
column5: one caused the other']"	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that the rainbow is responsible for the speaker making the basketball team. However, even though the speaker made the team after the rainbow appeared, that doesn't necessarily mean that the rainbow was responsible. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as false causation.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text exemplifies the logical fallacy of false causation
column2: which occurs when someone assumes a cause-and-effect relationship based on the mere sequence of events. In this case
column3: the speaker believes that the appearance of a rainbow led to their success in making the basketball team
column4: despite no evidence supporting that the rainbow had any influence. This fallacy highlights the flawed reasoning that because two events occurred in conjunction
column5: one must have caused the other
column6: which is not necessarily true."

column1: Which is a run-on sentence?	['All the things in the back of the closet.'

Knows the answer.

Who knows the answer? She knows the answer.
The bright red car.
This is a sentence fragment. It is missing a verb.
What did the bright red car do? The bright red car stopped.
A run-on sentence is made up of two sentences that are joined without end punctuation or with just a comma.
I knocked on the door it opened.

column2: we ran inside.

column1: I knocked on the door
column2: and it opened.

column1: It started raining

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"Mer's genotype for the tail spots gene is ii. Mer's genotype of ii has only i alleles. The i allele is for an unspotted tail. So
column6: Mer's phenotype for the tail spots trait must be an unspotted tail.

column1: To check this answer

column3: and i is a recessive allele.

column1: Mer's genotype of ii has only recessive alleles. An organism with only recessive alleles for a gene will have the recessive allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Mer's phenotype for the tail spots trait must be an unspotted tail."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Mer has a homozygous genotype of ii for the tail spots gene
column2: which consists only of recessive alleles. The allele for an unspotted tail (i) is recessive
column3: meaning that when an organism has two copies of this allele

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
The text argues that President Ballard is an effective communicator because he communicates well. However
column2: the ""evidence"" is just a restatement of the claim itself. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as circular reasoning."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The text presents an argument that President Ballard is an effective communicator based on the premise that he has a natural talent for speaking with people. However
column2: this reasoning is circular
column3: as it essentially restates the claim without providing any independent evidence or support. This type of reasoning fails to establish a valid connection between the premise and conclusion
column4: making it a clear example of circular reasoning."

column1: "Which figure of speech is used in this text?

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face."	"The text uses an allusion
column2: a brief reference to someone or something well known.

column1: Benedict Arnold alludes to the American general during the Revolutionary War who betrayed his country and fought for the British."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text employs an allusion by referencing Benedict Arnold
column2: a historical figure known for his betrayal during the American Revolutionary War. This reference evokes the concept of betrayal without explicitly explaining it
column3: relying on the reader's prior knowledge of Arnold's actions. The use of his name in this context suggests that Peter's actions are similarly treacherous
column4: making the comparison clear and impactful. Thus
column5: the correct choice is allusion
column6: as it connects the text to a broader historical narrative."

column1: Which text uses the word literally in its traditional sense?	"[""The curry that the chef prepared was so spicy that Julian's mouth was literally on fire by the time he finished his meal.""

column3: the word peruse once only meant to examine in detail

column1: When a word changes in meaning

column3: many people consider a word's traditional definition to be the correct usage. Being able to distinguish the different uses of a word can help you use it appropriately for different audiences.

column1: The traditional usage above is considered more standard.

column1: "Which type of sentence is this?

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought that can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause (or subordinate clause) is not a complete thought and cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.
Ben and I spent all day relaxing by the pool.
Some simple sentences have introductory phrases
column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column1: In the winter
column2: Ben usually wears his heavy coat.

column1: Ben usually wears his heavy coat in the winter.
A compound sentence is made up of two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction such as and
column2: but
column3: or
column4: or so.

column1: We saw the flash of lightning
column2: and seconds later we heard a rumble of thunder.

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause in a complex sentence usually begins with a subordinating conjunction or relative pronoun. Subordinating conjunctions include after
column2: although
column3: as
column4: because
column5: before
column6: if
column7: since
column8: unless
column9: until
column11: and while. Relative pronouns include that

column1: During his trip to Italy
column2: Tony visited the Trevi Fountain
column3: which is in Rome.

column1: A compound-complex sentence is made up of two or more independent clauses and one or more dependent clauses.
After Samantha left work
column2: she stopped at the bank
column3: and then she went to the gym.

column1: Sometimes a dependent clause in a complex or compound-complex sentence can interrupt an independent clause.
Orcas that are kept in captivity often have bent dorsal fins."	"The sentence is simple. It is a single independent clause.
Lee took several incredible panoramic photographs of the sweeping view from the top of Table Mountain."	"ANSWER: 3

SOLUTION: The sentence is best classified as a simple sentence because it contains only one independent clause with a subject (""Lee"") and a predicate (""took several incredible panoramic photographs""). It does not contain any dependent clauses or additional independent clauses that would characterize it as compound
column2: complex
column3: or compound-complex. The structure is straightforward and does not include conjunctions or additional clauses that would complicate its classification."

column1: Based on this information

column3: 'a black coat']	1	"In a group of horses

column5: the gene for the coat color trait has two alleles. The allele for a reddish-brown coat (l) is recessive to the allele for a black coat (L).

column1: Toriel is a horse from this group. Toriel has the homozygous genotype LL for the coat color gene."	closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Genetics vocabulary: dominant and recessive	"All organisms have pieces of hereditary material called genes
column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance
column4: its behavior
column5: and which diseases it may have. Genes may have different alleles
column6: or forms
column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color gene—one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"Toriel's genotype for the coat color gene is LL. Toriel's genotype of LL has only L allelles. The L allele is for a black coat. So
column6: Toriel's phenotype for the coat color trait must be a black coat.

column1: To check this answer
column2: consider whether Toriel's alleles are dominant or recessive. The allele for a reddish-brown coat (l) is recessive to the allele for a black coat (L). This means L is a dominant allele
column3: and l is a recessive allele.

column1: Toriel's genotype of LL has two dominant alleles. An organism with at least one dominant allele for a gene will have the dominant allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Toriel's phenotype for the coat color trait must be a black coat."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Toriel's genotype is homozygous dominant (LL) for the coat color gene
column2: where the dominant allele (L) corresponds to a black coat. Since the recessive allele (l) for a reddish-brown coat does not appear in the genotype
column3: Toriel must express the phenotype associated with the dominant allele. Therefore
column4: Toriel's phenotype for the coat color trait is a black coat
column5: confirming the choice of option (1)."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column2: 'Both are only physical changes.'
column3: 'Both are chemical changes.'

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So

Step 2: Look at each answer choice.

Both are caused by heating.
Neither change is caused by heating.

SOLUTION: Both erosion caused by wind and mixing sand and water are classified as physical changes. In both cases

column3: while mixing sand and water does not create a new substance. Therefore

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=246x241 at 0x312DAE4E0>	What is the expected ratio of offspring with a white body to offspring with a brown body? Choose the most likely ratio.	['4:0'

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with a white body or a brown body
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the body color trait. The question tells you that the b allele
column3: which is for a white body
column4: is recessive to the B allele
column5: which is for a brown body.

column1: A white body is the recessive allele's version of the body color trait. A Channel catfish with the recessive version of the body color trait must have only recessive alleles for the body color gene. So
column2: offspring with a white body must have the genotype bb.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype bb.

A brown body is the dominant allele's version of the body color trait. A Channel catfish with the dominant version of the body color trait must have at least one dominant allele for the body color gene. So
column2: offspring with a brown body must have the genotype BB or Bb.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype BB or Bb.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with a white body to offspring with a brown body is 0:4. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will never produce offspring with a white body. Instead
column5: this cross is expected to always produce offspring with a brown body."	"ANSWER: 2

column1: SOLUTION: The expected ratio of offspring with a white body to offspring with a brown body is determined by the genotypes produced in the Punnett square. Since the allele for a white body (b) is recessive
column2: it requires two recessive alleles (bb) to express that phenotype
column3: while a brown body can be represented by either the homozygous dominant (BB) or heterozygous (Bb) genotypes. As indicated in the analysis
column4: the Punnett square reveals that no offspring will have the genotype bb
column5: confirming that the ratio of white to brown bodies is 0:4. Therefore
column6: the most likely ratio is 0:4
column7: indicating that all offspring will have a brown body."

column1: "Which figure of speech is used in this text?

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face."	"The text uses personification
column2: giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.

column1: Edgar's '64 Impala groaned describes the car as if it were human."	"ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text employs personification

column3: thereby enhancing the emotional resonance of the narrative. In contrast
column4: a metaphor would require a direct comparison between two unlike things without using ""like"" or ""as
column5: which is not present in this text. Thus
column6: personification is the correct figure of speech used here."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column1: In a chemical change

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it re­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So

Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. No new matter is created.
Both are chemical changes.

Neither change is caused by heating.

column6: while mixing milk with oatmeal creates a mixture without changing the chemical structure of either component. Thus
column7: the correct answer is that both are only physical changes."

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Tyler must be fiscally irresponsible, because he works for a company that went bankrupt. However, even though his company is perceived as fiscally irresponsible, that doesn't necessarily mean that Tyler is, too. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text employs the logical fallacy of guilt by association by implying that Tyler is untrustworthy with money simply because he works for a company that has filed for bankruptcy. This fallacy discredits Tyler based on his association with the company rather than evaluating his individual financial responsibility or capabilities. The argument fails because it does not provide any evidence of Tyler's personal financial behavior
column2: demonstrating that the conclusion about his trustworthiness is unfounded and biased."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Did you really vote for Edgar as class treasurer? Didn't you hear that his uncle was imprisoned for embezzling $1.5 million?"	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column2: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']"	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Edgar can't be trusted with money, because his uncle embezzled money. However, even though his uncle couldn't be trusted with money, that doesn't necessarily mean that Edgar can't be trusted with it. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text presents a scenario where Edgar's potential trustworthiness is questioned based on his uncle's criminal actions
column2: which exemplifies the guilt by association fallacy. This fallacy occurs when someone is discredited not based on their own actions or character
column3: but rather due to negative associations with others. In this case
column4: the implication is that Edgar's uncle's wrongdoing reflects poorly on him
column5: despite there being no direct evidence of Edgar's own behavior or integrity. Thus
column6: the correct answer is guilt by association."

column1: "Which type of sentence is this?

column7: or compound-complex?	"A clause is a group of words that contains both a subject and a predicate.

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought that can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause (or subordinate clause) is not a complete thought and cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.
Ben and I spent all day relaxing by the pool.
Some simple sentences have introductory phrases
column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column1: In the winter
column2: Ben usually wears his heavy coat.

column1: Ben usually wears his heavy coat in the winter.
A compound sentence is made up of two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction such as and
column2: but
column3: or
column4: or so.

column1: We saw the flash of lightning
column2: and seconds later we heard a rumble of thunder.

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause in a complex sentence usually begins with a subordinating conjunction or relative pronoun. Subordinating conjunctions include after
column2: although
column3: as
column4: because
column5: before
column6: if
column7: since
column8: unless
column9: until
column11: and while. Relative pronouns include that

column1: If she ever gets the chance

column1: During his trip to Italy
column2: Tony visited the Trevi Fountain
column3: which is in Rome.

column1: A compound-complex sentence is made up of two or more independent clauses and one or more dependent clauses.

column2: she stopped at the bank
column3: and then she went to the gym.

column1: Sometimes a dependent clause in a complex or compound-complex sentence can interrupt an independent clause.
Orcas that are kept in captivity often have bent dorsal fins."	"The sentence is simple. It is a single independent clause.

SOLUTION: The sentence ""Bert took several incredible panoramic photographs of the sweeping view from the top of Table Mountain"" is classified as a simple sentence because it contains only one independent clause with a subject (""Bert"") and a predicate (""took several incredible panoramic photographs of the sweeping view from the top of Table Mountain""). There are no dependent clauses or additional clauses that would indicate a compound or complex structure. Therefore
column2: the correct choice is 2
column3: representing a simple sentence."

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.

A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.

A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.

Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.

Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.

A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.

Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Leah should either stop reading those sappy paranormal romance novels or finally admit that she doesn't believe in empowering women."	['bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct'
column2: 'slippery slope fallacy: the false assumption that a small first step will lead to extreme consequences'
column3: 'false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist']	2		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Leah either must give up reading a certain type of book or admit she doesn't believe in female empowerment. However, someone can both enjoy reading paranormal romance books and also believe in empowering women. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a false dichotomy.	ANSWER: 2

SOLUTION: The statement presents Leah with only two options: either stop reading paranormal romance novels or admit to not believing in empowering women. This creates a false dichotomy because it ignores the possibility that Leah can hold both views simultaneously—she can enjoy those novels and still be an advocate for women's empowerment. By limiting the choices to just these two
column2: the argument oversimplifies the situation and misrepresents the range of beliefs Leah may hold. Thus
column3: the logical fallacy identified here is indeed a false dichotomy."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
carving a piece of wood
water boiling on a stove"	['Both are chemical changes.'
column2: 'Both are only physical changes.'
column3: 'Both are caused by cooling.'
column4: 'Both are caused by heating.']	1		closed choice	grade3	natural science	chemistry	Physical and chemical change	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Chemical changes and physical changes are two common ways matter can change.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the type of matter changes. The types of matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. When paper gets hot enough
column3: it re­acts with oxygen in the air and burns. The paper and oxygen change into ash and smoke.

column1: In a physical change
column2: the type of matter stays the same. The types of matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: ice melting is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Ice and liquid water are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Carving a piece of wood is a physical change. The wood changes shape
column2: but it is still made of the same type of matter.

column1: Water boiling on the stove is a change of state. So
column2: it is a physical change. The liquid changes into a gas
column3: but a different type of matter is not formed.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. No new matter is created.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are physical changes. They are not chemical changes.
Both are caused by heating.
Water boiling is caused by heating. But carving a piece of wood is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: Both carving a piece of wood and water boiling on a stove are examples of physical changes
column2: where the substance retains its original properties. In the case of carving
column3: the wood changes shape but remains wood
column4: while boiling water changes from liquid to gas without altering its chemical composition. Therefore
column5: the correct answer is that both changes are only physical changes
column6: as no new substances are formed in either process."

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face."	"The text uses a pun

column3: illustrating Alana's journey in confronting her fears in a lighthearted manner. Thus
column4: the use of ""hurdle"" exemplifies the cleverness of a pun."

column4: or simply plates. The breaks between plates are called plate boundaries. Plate boundaries are classified by the way the plates are moving relative to each other:

column1: At a transform boundary
column2: two plates are sliding past each other.

column1: At a convergent boundary
column2: two plates are moving toward each other.

column1: At a divergent boundary
column2: two plates are moving away from each other.

column1: divergent plate boundary
When plates at a divergent boundary move apart
column2: cracks form in the crust along the boundary. Melted rock rises from below the crust to fill these cracks. As the melted rock cools and hardens
column3: it becomes new oceanic crust.

column1: Newer oceanic crust weighs less than older oceanic crust. So
column2: the crust on either side of the boundary rises up higher than the older crust that is farther from the boundary. This difference in elevation creates a mid-ocean ridge
column3: or underwater mountain chain. Between the two plates
column4: there may be a deep rift valley."	"To figure out what type of plate boundary formed the Aden Ridge
column5: you need to know how the tectonic plates interacted. To find this out

column1: The Aden Ridge began to form millions of years ago as the Somalian Plate and the Arabian Plate moved away from each other. The plates are slowly moving apart at a rate of about 2 centimeters per year. On the map
column2: the ridge is shown in the Gulf of Aden
column3: between the countries of Somalia and Yemen.

column1: The underlined part of the passage explains that the Aden Ridge formed as the two plates moved away from each other
column2: or diverged. So
column3: the Aden Ridge formed at a divergent boundary."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The passage clearly states that the Somalian Plate and the Arabian Plate are moving away from each other
column2: which indicates that the plates are diverging. This movement at a divergent boundary results in the formation of features like ridges. Therefore
column3: based on the description of the plate interaction and the type of boundary involved
column4: the correct answer is that the Aden Ridge formed at a divergent boundary."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

How can I be expected to do my homework when billions of people around the world are throwing their plastic water bottles away without recycling them?"	['circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself'
column2: 'red herring: the use of a completely unrelated topic or idea']	1		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that people not recycling somehow prevents the speaker from doing homework. However, these two ideas aren't related. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a red herring.	ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The text presents a situation where the speaker uses the issue of global plastic waste to divert attention from their responsibility to complete homework. This is an example of a red herring fallacy
column2: as it introduces an unrelated topic to distract from the main issue at hand. The argument does not logically connect the speaker's inability to do homework with others' recycling habits
column3: emphasizing the lack of relevance between the two points. Thus
column4: the speaker's reasoning is flawed due to this unrelated distraction."

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.

A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.

Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.

Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=248x239 at 0x312E045C0>	What is the expected ratio of offspring that do not have horns to offspring that have horns? Choose the most likely ratio.	['0:4'

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring that do or do not have horns
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the horns trait. The question tells you that the H allele
column3: which is for not having horns
column4: is dominant over the h allele
column5: which is for having horns.

column1: Not having horns is the dominant allele's version of the horns trait. A cow with the dominant version of the horns trait must have at least one dominant allele for the horns gene. So
column2: offspring that do not have horns must have the genotype HH or Hh.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype HH or Hh.
Having horns is the recessive allele's version of the horns trait. A cow with the recessive version of the horns trait must have only recessive alleles for the horns gene. So
column2: offspring that have horns must have the genotype hh.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype hh.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring that do not have horns to offspring that have horns is 4:0. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will always produce offspring that do not have horns. This cross is expected to never produce offspring that have horns."	"ANSWER: 2

column1: SOLUTION: The expected ratio of offspring that do not have horns to those that do is 4:0 based on the Punnett square analysis. Since the H allele is dominant and results in the phenotype of not having horns
column2: all offspring will inherit at least one dominant allele (H). Therefore
column3: none of the offspring will exhibit the recessive trait (having horns)
column4: resulting in a ratio of 4 offspring without horns to 0 offspring with horns. Thus
column5: the most likely ratio is 4:0."

column1: Temperature measures how hot or cold matter is. If the atoms in matter move faster
column2: the temperature goes up. The matter now has both more thermal energy and a higher temperature.

column1: What happens if the amount of matter changes? A 2-kilogram brick at 70°F has twice as much thermal energy as a 1-kilogram brick at 70°F. The two bricks have the same temperature
column2: but the larger brick has twice as many atoms. So

column2: the only variable affecting their thermal energy is temperature. Therefore
column3: the drop that is hotter possesses greater thermal energy compared to the colder drop. This is a fundamental principle of thermodynamics."

column1: "Which type of sentence is this?

column8: or compound-complex?	"A clause is a group of words that contains both a subject and a predicate.

column1: An independent clause is a complete thought that can stand alone as a sentence. A dependent clause (or subordinate clause) is not a complete thought and cannot stand alone as a sentence.
the oranges on our tree are ripe
The clause can stand alone. It is independent.
after we pick up Kevin from work
The clause cannot stand alone. It is dependent.
A simple sentence is made up of a single independent clause.
Ben and I spent all day relaxing by the pool.
Some simple sentences have introductory phrases
column2: but the introductory phrase is part of the predicate.

column1: In the winter
column2: Ben usually wears his heavy coat.

column1: Ben usually wears his heavy coat in the winter.
A compound sentence is made up of two independent clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction such as and
column2: but
column3: or
column4: or so.

column1: We saw the flash of lightning
column2: and seconds later we heard a rumble of thunder.

column1: A complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause in a complex sentence usually begins with a subordinating conjunction or relative pronoun. Subordinating conjunctions include after
column2: although
column3: as
column4: because
column5: before
column6: if
column7: since
column8: unless
column9: until
column11: and while. Relative pronouns include that

column1: If she ever gets the chance
column2: Terri would love to visit the Egyptian pyramids.

column1: During his trip to Italy
column2: Tony visited the Trevi Fountain
column3: which is in Rome.

column1: A compound-complex sentence is made up of two or more independent clauses and one or more dependent clauses.
After Samantha left work
column2: she stopped at the bank
column3: and then she went to the gym.

column1: Sometimes a dependent clause in a complex or compound-complex sentence can interrupt an independent clause.

Orcas that are kept in captivity often have bent dorsal fins."	"The sentence is complex. It is made up of an independent clause and a dependent clause. The dependent clause begins with the subordinating conjunction as.
As Matt sat down on the rickety old chair
column2: it abruptly collapsed beneath him."	"ANSWER: 2

column1: SOLUTION: The sentence is classified as complex because it contains one independent clause (""it abruptly collapsed beneath him"") and one dependent clause (""As Matt sat down on the rickety old chair""). The presence of the subordinating conjunction ""as"" indicates the beginning of the dependent clause
column2: which provides additional information about the timing of the action in the independent clause. Since it has both types of clauses
column3: it fits the definition of a complex sentence."

column1: Compare the motion of two birds. Which bird was moving at a higher speed?	['a bird that moved 15miles in 5hours'

Think about two objects moving for the same amount of time. The object that is moving faster will go a farther distance in that time. It is moving at a higher speed."	"Look at the distance each bird moved and the time it took to move that distance.
One bird moved 25 miles in 5 hours.
The other bird moved 15 miles in 5 hours.
Notice that each bird spent the same amount of time moving. The bird that moved 25 miles moved a farther distance in that time. So
column2: that bird must have moved at a higher speed."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: To determine which bird was moving at a higher speed
column2: we need to calculate the speed of each bird using the formula: speed = distance / time. The first bird moved 15 miles in 5 hours
column3: resulting in a speed of 3 miles per hour. The second bird moved 25 miles in 5 hours
column4: leading to a speed of 5 miles per hour. Since 5 miles per hour is greater than 3 miles per hour
column5: the second bird
column6: which moved 25 miles
column7: was moving at a higher speed."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Mr. Leonard can quit smoking because he's capable of stopping."	['circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself'
column2: 'hasty generalization: a broad claim based on too few observations'
column3: 'ad hominem: an attack against the person making the argument
column4: rather than the argument itself']	0		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
The text argues that Mr. Leonard can quit smoking because he is able to stop. However
column2: the ""evidence"" is just a restatement of the claim itself. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as circular reasoning."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The argument presented states that Mr. Leonard can quit smoking because he is capable of stopping
column2: which effectively rephrases the initial claim without providing any new evidence or reasoning. This is a classic example of circular reasoning
column3: where the conclusion is simply restated as the premise. In this case
column4: the argument does not advance beyond the assertion that he can quit
column5: failing to establish a valid basis for why he can do so. Thus
column6: the correct identification of the fallacy is circular reasoning."

column1: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?	['They passed the bill without too much trouble
column2: but it will not become law until the president has given his approval.'
column3: 'Legislators passed the bill without too much trouble
column4: but it will not become law until the president has given his approval.']	0		closed choice	grade10	language science	writing-strategies	Pronouns	Identify vague pronoun references	"When writing
column5: make sure to avoid vague pronoun references. A vague pronoun reference occurs when a pronoun could refer to more than one possible antecedent.

column1: When Lisa and Kim finally landed
column2: she breathed a sigh of relief.

column1: The pronoun she could refer to either Lisa or Kim
column2: so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.

column1: Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed
column2: Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.

column1: 2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.
A vague pronoun reference also occurs when they
column2: them
column3: their
column4: theirs
column5: it
column6: or its is used without its antecedent.

column1: They say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes.
The pronoun they is used without its antecedent
column2: so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.

column1: This problem can be fixed by replacing the pronoun with its missing antecedent.
The advertisements say that this nail polish dries in less than five minutes."	"The second answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference. The pronoun they is used without its antecedent.
The first answer choice shows a possible correction for the vague pronoun reference. They has been replaced with legislators.
Legislators passed the bill without too much trouble
column2: but it will not become law until the president has given his approval."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The first answer choice contains a vague pronoun reference due to the use of ""they
column2: which does not clearly identify the group of individuals who passed the bill. In contrast
column3: the second answer choice specifies ""Legislators
column4: removing the ambiguity and providing a clear antecedent for the pronoun. This distinction highlights how precise language improves clarity and understanding in writing. Therefore
column5: the first answer choice is the one with the vague pronoun reference."
