column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=236x241 at 0x312DBA750>	What is the expected ratio of offspring with bumpy fruit to offspring with smooth fruit? Choose the most likely ratio.	['3:1'

column1: This Punnett square shows a cross between two cucumber plants."	closed choice	grade8	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Use Punnett squares to calculate ratios of offspring types	"Offspring phenotypes: dominant or recessive?

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with bumpy fruit or smooth fruit
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the fruit texture trait. The question tells you that the F allele
column3: which is for bumpy fruit
column4: is dominant over the f allele
column5: which is for smooth fruit.

column1: Bumpy fruit is the dominant allele's version of the fruit texture trait. A cucumber plant with the dominant version of the fruit texture trait must have at least one dominant allele for the fruit texture gene. So
column2: offspring with bumpy fruit must have the genotype FF or Ff.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype FF or Ff.

Smooth fruit is the recessive allele's version of the fruit texture trait. A cucumber plant with the recessive version of the fruit texture trait must have only recessive alleles for the fruit texture gene. So
column2: offspring with smooth fruit must have the genotype ff.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype ff.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with bumpy fruit to offspring with smooth fruit is 0:4. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will never produce offspring with bumpy fruit. Instead
column5: this cross is expected to always produce offspring with smooth fruit."	"ANSWER: 0:4

column1: SOLUTION: The problem states that the allele for bumpy fruit (F) is dominant over the allele for smooth fruit (f). Given that all offspring from the cross in the Punnett square have the genotype ff
column2: it indicates that they all have smooth fruit. Since there are no offspring with the genotype FF or Ff
column3: the expected ratio of offspring with bumpy fruit to smooth fruit is 0:4
column4: meaning no bumpy fruit will be produced in this cross."

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.

column6: which rely on the ambiguity of language for humor and cleverness. Thus
column7: choice (1) pun is the correct answer."

column5: 'slippery slope fallacy: the false assumption that a small first step will lead to extreme consequences']	0		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Professor Harrell's research is untrustworthy because someone else at her university was caught falsifying data. However, this isn't necessarily true. The practices of one researcher at a university do not necessarily reflect the practices of another researcher at the same university. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text exemplifies the guilt by association fallacy because it discredits Professor Harrell's findings based solely on the actions of another researcher at her university. This reasoning is flawed as it assumes that the misconduct of one individual reflects the integrity of others in the same institution. Such an assumption lacks evidence and unfairly tarnishes Professor Harrell's credibility without direct proof of her own practices. Therefore
column2: the correct identification of the fallacy is guilt by association."

column1: "Complete the statement.
Zirconium is ()."	['a compound'
column2: 'an elementary substance']	1	Most of the zirconium produced every year is used in certain types of power plants to keep dangerous fuel from leaking. The chemical formula for zirconium is Zr.	closed choice	grade5	natural science	chemistry	Atoms and molecules	Classify elementary substances and compounds using chemical formulas	"Every substance around you is made of one or more chemical elements
column3: or types of atoms. Substances that are made of only one chemical element are elementary substances. Substances that are made of two or more chemical elements bonded together are compounds.

column1: Every chemical element is represented by its own symbol. For some elements
column2: the symbol is one capital letter. For other elements
column3: the symbol is one capital letter and one lowercase letter. For example
column4: the symbol for the element fluorine is F
column5: and the symbol for the element beryllium is Be.

column1: The symbol for each element in a substance is shown in the substance's chemical formula.
An elementary substance is represented by a chemical formula that contains only one symbol.

The symbol may be followed by a subscript. A subscript is text that is smaller and placed lower than the normal line of text. A subscript is included when the atoms in the elementary substance are bonded to form molecules. The subscript tells you the number of atoms in each molecule.
For example
column2: the chemical formula for the elementary substance oxygen is O2. The formula has a subscript of 2. This subscript tells you that there are two atoms in the molecule represented by this chemical formula.

column1: The chemical element represented by the symbol O is also called oxygen. So
column2: the formula O2 tells you that each molecule of O2 contains two oxygen atoms.

column1: A compound is represented by a chemical formula that contains multiple symbols.
For example
column2: in the compound beryllium fluoride
column3: there is one beryllium atom for every two fluorine atoms. This combination is shown in the compound's chemical formula
column4: BeF2. In the formula
column5: the symbol Be represents one beryllium atom. The symbol F followed by the subscript 2 represents two fluorine atoms."	"You can tell whether zirconium is an elementary substance or a compound by counting the number of symbols in its chemical formula. A symbol contains either one capital letter or a capital letter followed by one or two lowercase letters.

column1: The chemical formula for zirconium is Zr. This formula contains one symbol: Zr. So
column2: the formula tells you that zirconium is made of one chemical element.

column1: Substances made of only one chemical element are elementary substances. So
column2: zirconium is an elementary substance."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Zirconium is represented by the chemical symbol Zr
column2: which consists of only one symbol. This indicates that zirconium is composed of a single chemical element rather than being a compound made of multiple elements. Since substances that consist of only one chemical element are classified as elementary substances
column3: zirconium falls into this category. Hence
column4: the correct choice is that zirconium is an elementary substance."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=244x241 at 0x311ADC800>	What is the expected ratio of offspring with straight fur to offspring with curly fur? Choose the most likely ratio.	['2:2'
column5: '4:0']	4	"In a group of cats
column6: some individuals have straight fur and others have curly fur. In this group
column7: the gene for the fur type trait has two alleles. The allele for curly fur (f) is recessive to the allele for straight fur (F).

column1: This Punnett square shows a cross between two cats."	closed choice	grade8	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Use Punnett squares to calculate ratios of offspring types	"Offspring phenotypes: dominant or recessive?

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with straight fur or curly fur
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the fur type trait. The question tells you that the f allele
column3: which is for curly fur
column4: is recessive to the F allele
column5: which is for straight fur.

column1: Straight fur is the dominant allele's version of the fur type trait. A cat with the dominant version of the fur type trait must have at least one dominant allele for the fur type gene. So
column2: offspring with straight fur must have the genotype FF or Ff.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype FF or Ff.
Curly fur is the recessive allele's version of the fur type trait. A cat with the recessive version of the fur type trait must have only recessive alleles for the fur type gene. So
column2: offspring with curly fur must have the genotype ff.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype ff.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with straight fur to offspring with curly fur is 4:0. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will always produce offspring with straight fur. This cross is expected to never produce offspring with curly fur."	"ANSWER: 4:0

column1: SOLUTION: The problem describes a genetic cross involving two cats where the allele for straight fur (F) is dominant over the allele for curly fur (f). Since the offspring can only inherit the dominant allele F from both parents
column2: all combinations (FF or Ff) will result in straight fur. The Punnett square analysis shows that there are no combinations that yield curly fur (ff)
column3: leading to an expected ratio of 4:0 for straight fur to curly fur. Thus
column4: this cross will result in all offspring having straight fur."

column1: Temperature measures how hot or cold matter is. If the atoms in matter move faster

column1: "Complete the sentence.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form new molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Burning a piece of paper is a chemical change. As paper burns
column2: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then relink and form different molecules. For example
column3: carbon dioxide molecules are created when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water."	"Ice melting in a cup is a change of state. So

column1: The links between atoms in the water molecules do not change. So

column1: SOLUTION: Ice melting in a cup is a physical change because it involves a change of state from solid to liquid without altering the chemical composition of the water. column2: this confirms that it is a physical change rather than a chemical change."

An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.

A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.

A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.

Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.

Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.

Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.

column1: "Which figure of speech is used in this text?

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.
What a lucky little lady you are!
An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.
Olivia seems thrilled that her car keeps breaking down.
Each breakdown is as enjoyable as a punch to the face."	"The text uses an allusion
column2: a brief reference to someone or something well known.

column3: as most readers will recognize the significance of the reference. In contrast
column4: a simile would involve a direct comparison using ""like"" or ""as
column5: which is not present in the text. Thus
column6: the use of a well-known name to signify disloyalty points to an allusion rather than a simile."

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?
silver jewelry tarnishing
boiling sugar to make caramel"	['Both are only physical changes.'
column2: 'Both are caused by heating.'
column3: 'Both are caused by cooling.'
column4: 'Both are chemical changes.']	3		closed choice	grade8	natural science	chemistry	Chemical reactions	Compare physical and chemical changes	"Matter is made of very small particles called atoms. Atoms can be linked together by chemical bonds. When two or more atoms link together
column5: they form a molecule.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: The law of conservation of mass says that all physical and chemical changes conserve mass. Conserve means to keep the same. So
column2: the total mass before a physical or chemical change is equal to the total mass after the change."	"Step 1: Think about each change.

column1: Metal turning less shiny over time is called tarnishing. Silver jewelry tarnishing is a chemical change. The silver reacts with sulfur in the air to form black tarnish. The tarnish is a different type of matter that was not there before the change.
Boiling sugar to make caramel is a chemical change. The heat causes the sugar to change into a different type of matter. Unlike sugar
column2: the new matter is brown and sticky.

column1: Step 2: Look at each answer choice.
Both are only physical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. They are not physical changes.
Both are chemical changes.
Both changes are chemical changes. The type of matter before and after each change is different.
Both are caused by heating.
Boiling sugar is caused by heating. But silver tarnishing is not.
Both are caused by cooling.
Neither change is caused by cooling."	"ANSWER: 3
SOLUTION: Both changes—silver jewelry tarnishing and boiling sugar to make caramel—are chemical changes. In tarnishing
column2: silver reacts with sulfur in the air
column3: forming a different substance that alters the appearance of the jewelry. Similarly
column4: boiling sugar causes it to undergo a transformation into caramel
column5: which is a distinct substance. Therefore
column6: the correct answer is that both are chemical changes."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
The human resource department is urging the company to offer free gym memberships to all employees. They'd rather our employees be at the gym morning
column2: noon
column3: and night
column4: than get any work done."	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column5: 'bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct']"	0		closed choice	grade8	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column6: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that free gym memberships will result in lower productivity. However, offering free gym memberships doesn't necessarily suggest that employees will spend all their time at the gym rather than at work. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a straw man.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text presents a distorted version of the human resource department's proposal by implying that offering free gym memberships would lead employees to prioritize gym time over work. This misrepresentation simplifies the argument
column2: making it easier to attack by suggesting an extreme outcome that is not necessarily true. This exemplifies the straw man fallacy
column3: as it does not accurately reflect the original position regarding the gym memberships."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=243x239 at 0x312CA9580>	What is the expected ratio of offspring with blue body feathers to offspring with green body feathers? Choose the most likely ratio.	['4:0'

How do you determine an organism's phenotype for a trait? Look at the combination of alleles in the organism's genotype for the gene that affects that trait. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of the trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
If an organism's genotype has at least one dominant allele for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the dominant allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: If an organism's genotype has only recessive alleles for a gene
column2: the organism's phenotype will be the recessive allele's version of the gene's trait.

column1: A Punnett square shows what types of offspring a cross can produce. The expected ratio of offspring types compares how often the cross produces each type of offspring
column2: on average. To write this ratio
column3: count the number of boxes in the Punnett square representing each type.

column1: For example
column2: consider the Punnett square below.

column1: | F | f
F | FF | Ff
f | Ff | ff
There is 1 box with the genotype FF and 2 boxes with the genotype Ff. So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with the genotype FF to those with Ff is 1:2.

column1: To determine how many boxes in the Punnett square represent offspring with blue body feathers or green body feathers
column2: consider whether each phenotype is the dominant or recessive allele's version of the body feather color trait. The question tells you that the B allele
column3: which is for green body feathers
column4: is dominant over the b allele
column5: which is for blue body feathers.

column1: Blue body feathers is the recessive allele's version of the body feather color trait. A budgerigar parakeet with the recessive version of the body feather color trait must have only recessive alleles for the body feather color gene. So
column2: offspring with blue body feathers must have the genotype bb.

column1: There are 0 boxes in the Punnett square with the genotype bb.

Green body feathers is the dominant allele's version of the body feather color trait. A budgerigar parakeet with the dominant version of the body feather color trait must have at least one dominant allele for the body feather color gene. So
column2: offspring with green body feathers must have the genotype BB or Bb.

column1: All 4 boxes in the Punnett square have the genotype BB or Bb.
So
column2: the expected ratio of offspring with blue body feathers to offspring with green body feathers is 0:4. This means that
column3: based on the Punnett square
column4: this cross will never produce offspring with blue body feathers. Instead
column5: this cross is expected to always produce offspring with green body feathers."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The expected ratio of offspring with blue body feathers to those with green body feathers is 0:4
column2: indicating that no offspring would have blue feathers and all would have green. This conclusion is drawn from the genetic information provided: since the allele for green (B) is dominant over the allele for blue (b)
column3: any combination of alleles (BB or Bb) results in green body feathers. Therefore
column4: no boxes in the Punnett square correspond to the genotype bb
column5: confirming that all offspring will exhibit the dominant phenotype."

Lines of longitude are also called meridians. They show how far east or west a place is. We use degrees to help describe how far a place is from the prime meridian. column1: Which of the following contains a vague pronoun reference?	"[""Several competent city council members have been elected in Seaside

column1: The pronoun she could refer to either Lisa or Kim
column2: so the meaning of the sentence is unclear.

column1: Vague pronoun references can be corrected in one of two ways:
1. Replace the pronoun with its correct antecedent:
When Lisa and Kim finally landed
column2: Lisa breathed a sigh of relief.

column1: 2. Rewrite the sentence:
Lisa breathed a sigh of relief when she and Kim finally landed.

column2: them
column3: their
column4: theirs
column5: it

column1: "Complete the sentence.

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form new molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column3: carbon dioxide molecules are created when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change
column2: chemical bonds do not break. The types of molecules in matter before and after a physical change are always the same.

column2: water vaporizing is a physical change. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water."	"Mixing copper and tin to make bronze is a physical change. To make bronze

column2: and it opened.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Neil
column2: you didn't vote in the last election
column3: so you clearly have no regard for the democracy in which we live."	['red herring: the use of a completely unrelated topic or idea'
column4: 'false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist']	1		closed choice	grade7	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Neil must not care about democracy, because he didn't vote in the election. However, there may be a number of reasons why Neil didn't vote in the election. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a false dichotomy.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text presents a situation where Neil's lack of voting is used to conclude that he has no regard for democracy
column2: which implies that the only two choices are to either vote and care about democracy or not vote and not care about it. This is a classic example of a false dichotomy
column3: as it ignores other potential reasons for not voting
column4: such as personal circumstances or beliefs. By framing the argument in such binary terms
column5: the fallacy oversimplifies a complex issue."

column1: As a result of diffusion
column2: the concentration of solute particles becomes equal throughout the solution. When this happens

column1: Membranes

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column1: In a chemical change
column2: the chemical bonds in the molecules break. The atoms then link together to form different molecules. The types of molecules in matter before and after a chemical change are always different.

column1: Some chemical changes are caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: burning a piece of paper is a chemical change caused by heating. As paper burns
column3: paper molecules react with oxygen molecules in the air. This reaction breaks the chemical bonds in the molecules. The atoms then link together in a different way to form different molecules. For example
column4: carbon dioxide molecules are formed when paper burns.

column1: In a physical change

column1: A change of state is a type of physical change. Changes of state can be caused by heating or cooling. For example
column2: water vaporizing is a physical change that can be caused by heating. Liquid water and water vapor are made of the same type of matter: water.

column1: Milk going sour is a chemical change. The type of matter in the milk slowly changes. The new matter that is formed gives the milk its sour taste.

Both are chemical changes.

column6: the commonality between the two changes is that they both result in new substances formed through chemical reactions."

column1: Assonance is the repetition of a vowel sound in a series of nearby words.

column1: Hyperbole is an obvious exaggeration that is not meant to be taken literally.

column1: Always expect the unexpected.

column1: Winnee is a cow from this group. Winnee has the homozygous genotype aa for the coat pattern gene."	closed choice	grade6	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Genetics vocabulary: dominant and recessive	"All organisms have pieces of hereditary material called genes
column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance
column4: its behavior
column5: and which diseases it may have. Genes may have different alleles
column6: or forms
column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color gene—one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"Winnee's genotype for the coat pattern gene is aa. Winnee's genotype of aa has only a alleles. The a allele is for white spots. So
column6: Winnee's phenotype for the coat pattern trait must be white spots.

column1: To check this answer

column3: and a is a recessive allele.

column1: Winnee's genotype of aa has only recessive alleles. An organism with only recessive alleles for a gene will have the recessive allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Winnee's phenotype for the coat pattern trait must be white spots."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Winnee has the homozygous genotype aa for the coat pattern gene
column2: which consists of only recessive alleles. The allele for white spots (a) is recessive
column3: meaning that when an organism has two copies of the recessive allele (aa)
column4: it will express the trait associated with that allele
column5: which is white spots. Since the allele for solid coloring (A) is dominant
column6: Winnee does not have any A alleles to express that phenotype. Thus
column7: Winnee's phenotype for the coat pattern trait is determined to be white spots."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Ronald
column2: you drive a beat-up car from the 1980s. For this reason
column3: we can never allow you to be a lifeguard at the community pool."	"['false dichotomy: an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist'
column4: ""ad hominem: a personal attack against one's opponent""]"	1		closed choice	grade7	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that people who drive old cars are likely to be poor lifeguards. This is a personal attack that isn't relevant to someone's qualifications to be a lifeguard. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The text employs an ad hominem fallacy by attacking Ronald's character based on his choice of vehicle rather than addressing his qualifications as a lifeguard. This logical fallacy diverts attention from the relevant issue of competence and instead focuses on a personal trait
column2: implying that his old car reflects negatively on his abilities. By using this irrelevant personal attack
column3: the argument fails to provide a valid reason for disqualifying him from the position."

column1: Every chemical element is represented by its own symbol. For some elements

The symbol may be followed by a subscript. A subscript is text that is smaller and placed lower than the normal line of text. A subscript is included when the atoms in the elementary substance are bonded to form molecules. The subscript tells you the number of atoms in each molecule.

column2: the chemical formula for the elementary substance oxygen is O2. The formula has a subscript of 2. This subscript tells you that there are two atoms in the molecule represented by this chemical formula.

column1: A compound is represented by a chemical formula that contains multiple symbols.

column4: BeF2. In the formula

column1: "Does the sentence use a simile or a metaphor?

column1: A simile compares two things by saying that one is like the other. Similes often use the words like and as.

The sister's running and a cheetah's running are compared using the word like.
A cheetah is known for running fast
column2: so the simile means that the sister also runs fast.

column1: The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
The cat's fur and the night are compared using the word as.
The night is dark
column2: so the simile means that the cat's fur is also dark.

column1: A metaphor compares two things by saying that one of them is the other. Unlike similes
column2: metaphors don't use the word like or as.

column1: The snow formed a blanket over the town.
The snow and a blanket are compared without the word like or as.
A blanket is a large piece of cloth that completely covers a bed. The metaphor makes the reader imagine that the snow becomes a blanket
column2: covering the town completely.

column1: Using similes and metaphors in your writing can help you create an interesting picture for the reader."	"Jayla went down the slide face-first
column2: like a penguin.

column1: The words Jayla and penguin are compared using the word like. So
column2: the sentence uses a simile."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The sentence ""Jayla went down the slide face-first
column2: like a penguin"" employs the word ""like"" to draw a comparison between Jayla's action and that of a penguin. This use of ""like"" is a key characteristic of similes
column3: which directly compare two different things to create a vivid image. In contrast
column4: a metaphor would assert that one thing is another without using ""like"" or ""as."" Therefore
column5: since a comparison is made using ""like
column6: it confirms that this sentence is a simile."

column1: Assonance is the repetition of a vowel sound in a series of nearby words.

column1: Hyperbole is an obvious exaggeration that is not meant to be taken literally.

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=596x384 at 0x311ADC2F0>	What produces sperm and eggs?	['spores'

column2: and moss sperm can travel through water to the female parts.

column1: The sperm fuse with eggs in the female part. This is called fertilization. Self-fertilization happens when a sperm from a moss plant fertilizes an egg from the same plant. Cross-fertilization happens when a sperm from one moss plant fertilizes an egg from a different moss plant.

column2: the spores are released.

column4: they germinate and grow into new moss plants that can then produce gametes. Therefore
column5: the correct answer is an adult moss plant
column6: which corresponds to choice (1)."

column1: Which is a run-on sentence?	['During the game

column1: My friends walk along the path.
A sentence fragment is a group of words that does not express a complete thought. It is usually missing a subject or a verb.
Knows the answer.

Who knows the answer? She knows the answer.
The bright red car.

A run-on sentence is made up of two sentences that are joined without end punctuation or with just a comma.
I knocked on the door it opened.
It started raining
column2: we ran inside.

column1: To fix a run-on sentence
column2: separate it into two sentences. Add end punctuation after the first sentence
column3: and capitalize the second sentence.

column1: I knocked on the door. It opened.
It started raining. We ran inside.
You can also fix a run-on sentence by rewriting it as a compound sentence. A compound sentence is two sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction such as and

column4: or so.

column1: I knocked on the door
column2: and it opened.

column1: It started raining

column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color gene—one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"Tiki's genotype for the body feather color gene is bb. Tiki's genotype of bb has only b alleles. The b allele is for blue body feathers. So
column6: Tiki's phenotype for the body feather color trait must be blue body feathers.

column1: To check this answer
column2: consider whether Tiki's alleles are dominant or recessive. The allele for blue body feathers (b) is recessive to the allele for green body feathers (B). This means B is a dominant allele
column3: and b is a recessive allele.

column1: Tiki's genotype of bb has only recessive alleles. An organism with only recessive alleles for a gene will have the recessive allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Tiki's phenotype for the body feather color trait must be blue body feathers."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Tiki has the homozygous genotype bb for the body feather color gene
column2: where 'b' is the allele for blue body feathers. Since the allele for blue body feathers is recessive
column3: an organism with the genotype bb will express the blue phenotype. The dominant allele (B) for green body feathers is not present in Tiki's genotype
column4: confirming that Tiki's phenotype must be blue body feathers. Therefore
column5: the correct choice is (1) blue body feathers."

column1: Select the part whose main job is to use energy from sunlight to make sugar in a plant cell.	['chromosomes'
column2: 'chloroplasts'
column3: 'cell membrane'
column4: 'vacuole']	1		closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Cells	Identify functions of plant cell parts	"Plant cells are made up of many different parts. Each cell part has a function that helps the cell survive and grow.

column1: Some cell parts are called organelles. Organelles are cell structures that are surrounded by their own membranes. Here are some of the organelles in plant cells:

Chloroplasts and mitochondria work together to help the cell get the energy it needs. The chloroplasts use photosynthesis to make sugar. The mitochondria break down this sugar and release energy that the cell can use for all of its activities.

The nucleus directs cell activities by sending instructions to different parts of the cell. The nucleus contains structures called chromosomes. The chromosomes are made mostly of hereditary material called DNA. DNA contains information that the cell uses for growth and activities. These instructions tell ribosomes how to build molecules called proteins
column2: which make up cell structures and help chemical reactions happen in the cell.

column1: The endoplasmic reticulum is an organelle that helps ribosomes build proteins. The nucleus sends instructions for making proteins to ribosomes. Ribosomes can attach to the endoplamic reticulum. The endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes use these instructions to make proteins that the cell needs to survive and grow.
After proteins are made in the endoplasmic reticulum
column2: they can be transferred to the Golgi. The Golgi is an organelle made up of flat
column3: stacked membranes. The Golgi sorts and packages proteins and other substances. Then
column4: the Golgi sends these substances to different parts of the cell. Some of these substances are sent to the cell membrane and released from the cell.

column1: In plant cells
column2: the vacuole stores waste
column3: water
column4: and nutrients such as sugar. Most plant cells have one vacuole.

column1: Other cell parts are not surrounded by their own membranes. These cell parts are not organelles.
The cell wall is the cell's tough outer covering. It gives the cell strength and stiffness and helps the cell keep its shape.
On the inside of the cell wall is a thin layer called the cell membrane. This layer is a membrane
column2: but it does not have a membrane surrounding it
column3: so it is not an organelle. The cell membrane controls which substances enter and leave the cell.

column1: The cytoplasm is a thick liquid that fills the space inside the cell. The cytoplasm also helps the cell keep its shape and supports the other cell parts."	"Chloroplasts use photosynthesis to make sugar. First
column2: chloroplasts capture energy from sunlight. Then
column3: they use this energy to turn water and carbon dioxide gas into sugar
column4: the plant cell's food.

column1: A plant cell may have many chloroplasts. Chloroplasts contain a green substance called chlorophyll."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: Chloroplasts are the organelles in plant cells responsible for photosynthesis
column2: the process by which they convert sunlight into chemical energy in the form of sugar. They contain chlorophyll
column3: the green pigment that captures light energy. During photosynthesis
column4: chloroplasts utilize water and carbon dioxide
column5: transforming them into glucose
column6: which serves as food for the plant. Other options listed
column7: such as chromosomes
column8: cell membrane
column9: and vacuole
column10: do not have the primary function of converting sunlight into energy."

column1: "Which figure of speech is used in this text?

column2: but almost all his friends know."	['hyperbole'
column3: 'oxymoron']	1		closed choice	grade12	language science	figurative-language	Literary devices	Classify the figure of speech: review	"Figures of speech are words or phrases that use language in a nonliteral or unusual way. They can make writing more expressive.

column1: Anaphora is the repetition of the same word or words at the beginning of several phrases or clauses.
We are united. We are powerful. We are winners.
Antithesis involves contrasting opposing ideas within a parallel grammatical structure.
I want to help
column2: not to hurt.

column1: Apostrophe is a direct address to an absent person or a nonhuman entity.
Oh
column2: little bird
column3: what makes you sing so beautifully?

column1: Assonance is the repetition of a vowel sound in a series of nearby words.
Try to light the fire.
Chiasmus is an expression in which the second half parallels the first but reverses the order of words.
Never let a fool kiss you or a kiss fool you.
A euphemism is a polite or indirect expression that is used to de-emphasize an unpleasant topic.
The head of Human Resources would never refer to firing people
column2: only to laying them off.

column1: Hyperbole is an obvious exaggeration that is not meant to be taken literally.
I ate so much that I think I might explode!
An oxymoron is a joining of two seemingly contradictory terms.
Some reviewers are calling this book a new classic.
A paradox is a statement that might at first appear to be contradictory
column2: but that may in fact contain some truth.

column1: Always expect the unexpected.
Understatement involves deliberately representing something as less serious or important than it really is.
As you know
column2: it can get a little cold in the Antarctic."	"The text uses an oxymoron
column3: a joining of two seemingly contradictory terms.

column1: Open secret is a contradiction
column2: because open describes something that is freely or publicly known
column3: and a secret is hidden."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The phrase ""open secret"" is a classic example of an oxymoron
column2: where two opposing concepts are juxtaposed to create a unique meaning. In this case
column3: ""open"" implies that something is widely known
column4: while ""secret"" denotes that it is meant to be concealed. This contradiction effectively conveys the irony of the situation
column5: as it highlights that although Bryce's book writing is not openly discussed
column6: it is
column7: paradoxically
column8: a well-known fact among his friends. Thus
column9: the use of oxymoron emphasizes the complexity of knowledge and secrecy in social contexts."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=491x250 at 0x311ADE4B0>	Which of the following fossils is younger? Select the more likely answer.	['dinosaur footprint'

column3: the deeper layers are older than the shallower layers.

column5: the fern fossil is considered to be younger than the dinosaur footprint fossil

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=760x506 at 0x312CAFB30>	Which of the following organisms is the secondary consumer in this food web?	['persimmon tree'

column1: A food web models how the matter eaten by organisms moves through an ecosystem. The arrows in a food web represent how matter moves between organisms in an ecosystem."	closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Ecological interactions	Interpret food webs I	"A food web is a model.

column1: Arrows show how matter moves.

An organism in a food web can have more than one arrow pointing from it. This shows that the organism is eaten by more than one other organism in the food web.

column1: The swallowtail caterpillar has an arrow pointing to it from the persimmon tree. The persimmon tree is not a primary consumer

column1: The beaver has an arrow pointing to it from the silver maple. The silver maple is not a primary consumer
column2: so the beaver is not a secondary consumer.

column1: The persimmon tree does not have any arrows pointing to it. So

column1: The black bear has arrows pointing to it from the swallowtail caterpillar and the beaver. The swallowtail caterpillar and the beaver are primary consumers
column2: so the black bear is a secondary consumer.

column4: the black bear
column5: which preys on them
column6: fits the definition of a secondary consumer."

column1: "Complete the statement.

The chemical formula for 2-chloroethanol is C2H5ClO.	closed choice	grade6	natural science	chemistry	Atoms and molecules	Classify elementary substances and compounds using chemical formulas	"There are more than 100 different chemical elements
column3: or types of atoms. Chemical elements make up all of the substances around you.

column1: A substance may be composed of one chemical element or multiple chemical elements. Substances that are composed of only one chemical element are elementary substances. Substances that are composed of multiple chemical elements bonded together are compounds.
Every chemical element is represented by its own atomic symbol. An atomic symbol may consist of one capital letter
column2: or it may consist of a capital letter followed by a lowercase letter. For example
column3: the atomic symbol for the chemical element fluorine is F
column4: and the atomic symbol for the chemical element beryllium is Be.

column1: The atomic symbol for each chemical element in a substance is shown in the substance's chemical formula.
An elementary substance is represented by a chemical formula that contains only one atomic symbol.

The atomic symbol in a chemical formula may be followed by a small number written lower than the symbol. This number is called a subscript. A subscript is included when the atoms in the elementary substance are bonded to form molecules. The subscript shows how many atoms are in each molecule.
For example
column2: the chemical formula for the elementary substance oxygen
column3: O2
column4: has a subscript of 2. This subscript shows that the atomic symbol O represents two atoms. The elementary substance O2 and the chemical element represented by the atomic symbol O are both named oxygen. So
column5: the formula tells you that each molecule of O2 contains two oxygen atoms.

column1: A compound is represented by a chemical formula that contains multiple atomic symbols.
The chemical elements in a compound are bonded together in a fixed ratio. This ratio is shown in a compound's chemical formula.
For example
column2: in the compound beryllium fluoride
column3: there is one beryllium atom for every two fluorine atoms. So
column4: the ratio of beryllium atoms to fluorine atoms is 1 to 2. This ratio is shown in the chemical formula for beryllium fluoride
column5: BeF2. There is no subscript following the atomic symbol Be because that symbol represents one atom. The subscript 2 follows the atomic symbol F to show that the symbol represents two atoms."	"You can tell whether 2-chloroethanol is an elementary substance or a compound by counting the number of atomic symbols in its chemical formula. An atomic symbol consists of either one capital letter or a capital letter followed by one or two lowercase letters.

column1: The chemical formula for 2-chloroethanol
column2: C2 H5 ClO
column3: contains four atomic symbols: C for carbon
column4: H for hydrogen
column5: Cl for chlorine
column6: and O for oxygen. So
column7: the formula tells you that 2-chloroethanol is composed of four chemical elements bonded together.

column1: Since 2-chloroethanol is composed of multiple chemical elements bonded together
column2: 2-chloroethanol is a compound."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: I chose this answer because 2-chloroethanol is composed of multiple elements
column2: specifically carbon (C)
column3: hydrogen (H)
column4: chlorine (Cl)
column5: and oxygen (O)
column6: as indicated by its chemical formula C2H5ClO. This composition confirms that it is a compound rather than an elementary substance
column7: which consists of only one type of atom. The presence of more than one atomic symbol in the formula signifies that it is not a pure element but rather a chemical compound formed by the combination of different elements."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that being socially awkward determines knowledge of workplace safety. This is a personal attack that isn't relevant to Mr. Carlson's desire to prevent workplace injuries. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 0
SOLUTION: The text exemplifies the ad hominem logical fallacy
column2: where the argument attacks Mr. Carlson's character (his social awkwardness) instead of addressing the validity of his claims about workplace safety. This tactic undermines the discussion by shifting focus from the issue at hand to personal characteristics
column3: which are irrelevant to the argument. Therefore
column4: the reasoning presented does not engage with the actual topic of preventing workplace injuries
column5: making the ad hominem fallacy the correct choice."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=705x411 at 0x311ADC200>	Which of these continents does the prime meridian intersect?	['Antarctica'
column2: 'South America'
column3: 'North America']	0		closed choice	grade4	social science	geography	Maps	Use lines of latitude and longitude	"Lines of latitude and lines of longitude are imaginary lines drawn on some globes and maps. They can help you find places on globes and maps.

column1: Lines of latitude show how far north or south a place is. We use units called degrees to describe how far a place is from the equator. The equator is the line located at 0° latitude. We start counting degrees from there.
Lines north of the equator are labeled N for north. Lines south of the equator are labeled S for south. Lines of latitude are also called parallels because each line is parallel to the equator.

Lines of longitude are also called meridians. They show how far east or west a place is. We use degrees to help describe how far a place is from the prime meridian. The prime meridian is the line located at 0° longitude. Lines west of the prime meridian are labeled W. Lines east of the prime meridian are labeled E. Meridians meet at the north and south poles.
The equator goes all the way around the earth
column2: but the prime meridian is different. It only goes from the North Pole to the South Pole on one side of the earth. On the opposite side of the globe is another special meridian. It is labeled both 180°E and 180°W.

column1: Together
column2: lines of latitude and lines of longitude form a grid. You can use this grid to find the exact location of a place."	The prime meridian is the line at 0° longitude. It intersects Antarctica. It does not intersect South America or North America.	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The prime meridian
column2: which is established at 0° longitude
column3: primarily runs through Greenwich
column4: England
column5: and extends north and south. It intersects the continent of Antarctica as it travels through the southern hemisphere. However
column6: it does not pass through South America or North America
column7: making Antarctica the only continent among the provided choices that the prime meridian intersects."

column1: <PIL.PngImagePlugin.PngImageFile image mode=RGB size=596x384 at 0x312DE2F30>	What does a moss plant's thin brown stalk produce?	['eggs and sperm'
column2: 'spores']	1	This diagram shows the life cycle of a moss.	closed choice	grade7	natural science	biology	Plant reproduction	Moss and fern life cycles	"Moss plants reproduce using both asexual reproduction and sexual reproduction.

column1: Moss plants use their male and female parts for sexual reproduction. The male parts produce sperm. Moss live in damp environments
column2: and moss sperm can travel through water to the female parts.

column1: The sperm fuse with eggs in the female part. This is called fertilization. Self-fertilization happens when a sperm from a moss plant fertilizes an egg from the same plant. Cross-fertilization happens when a sperm from one moss plant fertilizes an egg from a different moss plant.

The fertilized egg grows into a thin brown stalk on top of the female part. Each stalk has a small spore capsule at the top. Moss plants use asexual reproduction to make small spores in the capsules. When the capsules open
column2: the spores are released.

column1: When the spores land on the ground
column2: they may germinate and grow into a new moss plant. This new moss plant can produce eggs and sperm and begin the moss life cycle again."	"The thin brown stalk produces spores. Spores are released from the capsule at the top of the stalk.

column1: The thin brown stalk does not produce eggs or sperm. They are produced by the female and male parts of the moss plant."	"ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The thin brown stalk of a moss plant specifically produces spores
column2: which are released from the capsule located at its top. This is a crucial part of the moss life cycle
column3: as spores are responsible for the reproduction and dispersal of the plant. In contrast
column4: eggs and sperm are produced by the separate male and female reproductive structures of the moss
column5: not by the stalk itself. Therefore
column6: the correct answer is that the stalk produces spores."

column1: Lines of latitude show how far north or south a place is. We use units called degrees to describe how far a place is from the equator. The equator is the line located at 0° latitude. We start counting degrees from there.
Lines north of the equator are labeled N for north. Lines south of the equator are labeled S for south. Lines of latitude are also called parallels because each line is parallel to the equator.

Lines of longitude are also called meridians. They show how far east or west a place is. We use degrees to help describe how far a place is from the prime meridian. The prime meridian is the line located at 0° longitude. Lines west of the prime meridian are labeled W. Lines east of the prime meridian are labeled E. Meridians meet at the north and south poles.
The equator goes all the way around the earth
column2: but the prime meridian is different. It only goes from the North Pole to the South Pole on one side of the earth. On the opposite side of the globe is another special meridian. It is labeled both 180°E and 180°W.

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Senator Pena announced today that she plans to cut funding to early childhood education programs. The last thing we need is a government official who hates children!"	"[""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""
column2: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']"	0		closed choice	grade6	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column3: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Senator Pena hates children, because she wants to cut education funding. However, the fact that Senator Pena wants to cut education funding doesn't necessarily suggest that she hates children. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as a straw man.	ANSWER: 0

SOLUTION: The text presents a misrepresentation of Senator Pena's position by equating her decision to cut funding with a hatred for children. This oversimplifies her stance and makes it easier to argue against her by attacking a distorted version of her position
column2: which aligns with the straw man fallacy. While guilt by association could also be argued
column3: the main focus is on the misrepresentation of her actions rather than an association with negative connotations. Therefore
column4: the straw man fallacy is the more appropriate choice."

column1: Alliteration is the repetition of sounds at the beginning of nearby words.

An allusion is a brief reference to something or someone well known
column2: often from history or literature.

column1: I'd better get home before I turn into a pumpkin!"" Lila remarked.
An idiom is an expression that cannot be understood literally. Its meaning must be learned.
The assignment was a piece of cake.
A simile uses like or as to compare two things that are not actually alike.
The cat's fur was as dark as the night.
A metaphor compares two things that are not actually alike without using like or as.
The snow formed a blanket over the town.
Onomatopoeia involves using a word that expresses a sound.
The scrambled eggs hit the floor with a splat.
Personification is giving human characteristics to nonhuman things.
The trees danced in the wind.
A pun involves using a word or phrase in a humorous way that suggests more than one meaning.
A great new broom is sweeping the nation.
Verbal irony involves saying one thing but implying something very different. People often use verbal irony when they are being sarcastic.

column4: making it clear that he does not genuinely enjoy skipping meals."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
How could Hazel have anything insightful to say about foreign affairs? She grew up on a farm."	['hasty generalization: a broad claim based on too few observations'
column2: 'ad hominem: an attack against the person making the argument
column3: rather than the argument itself'
column4: 'slippery slope fallacy: the false assumption that a small first step will lead to extreme consequences']	1		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column5: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Hazel cannot be insightful about foreign affairs because she grew up on a farm. This is a personal attack that isn't relevant to whether she knows about foreign affairs. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as ad hominem.	ANSWER: 1

SOLUTION: The text presents an argument that dismisses Hazel's potential insights on foreign affairs solely based on her background of growing up on a farm. This reasoning is irrelevant to her actual knowledge or capability regarding foreign affairs and instead attacks her character or circumstances. This type of fallacy is categorized as ad hominem
column2: where the focus is shifted from the argument itself to the individual's personal attributes."

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
The text argues that Mr. Harding can quit smoking because he is able to stop. However

column1: Based on this information

column3: 'not having horns']	1	"In a group of cows

column1: Zelda is a cow from this group. Zelda has the heterozygous genotype Hh for the horns gene."	closed choice	grade6	natural science	biology	Genes to traits	Genetics vocabulary: dominant and recessive	"All organisms have pieces of hereditary material called genes
column2: which are passed from parents to offspring. Genes contain instructions for building the parts of an organism. An organism's genes affect its observable traits
column3: including its appearance
column4: its behavior
column5: and which diseases it may have. Genes may have different alleles
column6: or forms
column7: that can cause different versions of a trait.

column1: For example
column2: flower color is a trait in pea plants. The gene for this trait has two possible alleles. Each allele is represented by an uppercase or lowercase letter. The allele F is for purple flowers
column3: and the allele f is for white flowers. Each pea plant has two alleles for the flower color gene—one allele inherited from each parent.

column1: An organism's genotype for a gene is its combination of alleles for that gene. So
column2: a pea plant may have a genotype of FF
column3: Ff
column4: or ff for the flower color gene.

column1: An organism's phenotype for a trait is its observable version of that trait
column2: which depends on the organism's combination of alleles. A pea plant may have a phenotype of purple flowers or white flowers for the flower color trait.

column1: Some traits
column2: like flower color in pea plants
column3: are controlled by a single gene. Most plants and animals have a genotype made up of two alleles for these traits. These two alleles determine whether an organism is homozygous or heterozygous for the gene.

column1: An organism with two identical alleles for a gene is homozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype FF or ff is homozygous for the flower color gene.
An organism with two different alleles for a gene is heterozygous for that gene. A pea plant with the genotype Ff is heterozygous for the flower color gene.

The types of alleles in an organism's genotype determine the organism's phenotype. Some alleles have types called dominant and recessive. These two types can cause different versions of a trait to appear as the organism's phenotype.
A dominant allele causes its version of the trait to appear even when the organism also has a recessive allele for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the F allele
column3: which causes purple flowers
column4: is dominant over the f allele. A pea plant with at least one F allele will have the F allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype FF or Ff will have purple flowers.

column1: A recessive allele causes its version of the trait to appear only when the organism does not have any dominant alleles for the gene. In pea plants
column2: the f allele
column3: which causes white flowers
column4: is recessive to the F allele. A pea plant with only f alleles will have the f allele's version of the flower color trait. So
column5: a plant with the genotype ff will have white flowers."	"You need to determine Zelda's phenotype for the horns trait. First
column6: consider the alleles in Zelda's genotype for the horns gene. Then
column7: decide whether these alleles are dominant or recessive.

column1: The allele for having horns (h) is recessive to the allele for not having horns (H). This means H is a dominant allele
column2: and h is a recessive allele.

column1: Zelda's genotype of Hh has one dominant allele and one recessive allele. An organism with at least one dominant allele for a gene will have the dominant allele's version of the trait. So
column2: Zelda's phenotype for the horns trait must be not having horns."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: Zelda has a heterozygous genotype of Hh for the horns trait
column2: where H (the allele for not having horns) is dominant over h (the allele for having horns). Since Zelda possesses the dominant allele (H)

column4: which means she does not have horns. Therefore

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
