column2: 'false causation: the assumption that because two things happened together
column3: one caused the other']	0		closed choice	grade6	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
The text argues that Carla is intelligent because she's smart. However
column2: the ""evidence"" is just a restatement of the claim itself. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as circular reasoning."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: The text employs circular reasoning
column2: which is a logical fallacy where the conclusion is supported by a premise that essentially restates the conclusion itself. In this case
column3: the claim that Carla is the most intelligent person is backed up by saying she is ""so smart
column4: which does not provide any new evidence or justification for the claim. Instead
column5: it reaffirms the assertion without offering any additional rationale
column6: exemplifying the nature of circular reasoning."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?

Senator Robinson isn't lying when she says she cares about her constituents—she wouldn't lie to people she cares about."	"['guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something'
column2: 'circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself'
column3: ""straw man: a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against""]"	1		closed choice	grade11	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against
The text argues that Senator Robinson isn't lying about caring for her constituents because she doesn't lie to people she cares about. However
column2: the ""evidence"" is just a restatement of the claim itself. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as circular reasoning."	"ANSWER: 1

column1: SOLUTION: The text demonstrates circular reasoning because it uses the premise that Senator Robinson cares about her constituents to justify the claim that she isn't lying about caring for them. Essentially
column2: the argument relies on the same assertion—her care for constituents—to prove itself
column3: without providing any independent evidence or reasoning. This fallacy occurs when the conclusion is derived from premises that assume the conclusion is true
column4: making the argument logically flawed."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
Don't try to tell me that you only watch educational programming
column2: Marie! I know for a fact that your sister only watches reality television."	['hasty generalization: a very broad claim based on very little evidence'
column3: 'guilt by association: a negative association intended to discredit someone or something']	1		closed choice	grade6	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column4: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | a personal attack meant to discredit one's opponent
appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
red herring | the use of a completely unrelated topic in support of a claim
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a very broad claim based on very little evidence
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that Marie must watch reality television, because her sister watches reality television. However, even though Marie's sister watches reality television, that doesn't necessarily mean that Marie does, too. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as guilt by association.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text presents an argument that tries to discredit Marie's claim of only watching educational programming by associating her with her sister
column2: who watches reality television. This is a classic example of guilt by association
column3: as it implies that because Marie's sister watches a certain type of programming
column4: Marie must as well. The fallacy lies in the assumption that familial or social connections dictate personal choices
column5: which is not logically sound. Therefore
column6: the argument does not provide valid evidence regarding Marie's viewing habits."

column1: "Which logical fallacy is used in the text?
It's true that pasteurization kills harmful bacteria in milk. But pasteurization is a process that was invented by humans. Instead
column2: we should drink milk raw
column3: pure
column4: and unchanged. It's better for us."	['bandwagon fallacy: the assumption that the popular choice is automatically correct'
column5: 'appeal to nature: the assumption that natural things are always good'
column6: 'circular reasoning: an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself']	1		closed choice	grade9	language science	writing-strategies	Developing and supporting arguments	Classify logical fallacies	"A strong argument uses valid reasoning and logic in support of a claim. When an argument or claim introduces irrelevant information or misrepresents the issues at hand
column7: it may be committing a logical fallacy. Logical fallacies can hurt a writer's credibility and can lead readers to draw false conclusions.

column1: A logical fallacy may present irrelevant information:
Fallacy | Description
ad hominem | an attack against the person making the argument
column2: rather than the argument itself

column1: appeal to nature | an argument that assumes the natural choice is always the best choice
bandwagon fallacy | an argument that assumes the popular choice is always the best choice
circular reasoning | an argument that supports a claim with the claim itself
guilt by association | an unfair negative association with another person or group that is intended to discredit someone or something
A logical fallacy may misrepresent the issues at hand:
Fallacy | Description
false causation | the assumption that because two things happened together
column2: one caused the other

column1: false dichotomy | an argument that presents only two choices when more options exist
hasty generalization | a broad claim based on too few observations
slippery slope fallacy | the false assumption that a small first step will necessarily lead to extreme consequences
straw man | a misrepresentation of an opponent's position that makes it easier to argue against

The text argues that raw milk is better than pasteurized milk because pasteurization isn't a natural process. However, raw milk isn't necessarily healthier for humans just because it's unprocessed. This illustrates a type of logical fallacy known as an appeal to nature.	ANSWER: 1
SOLUTION: The text suggests that raw milk is superior to pasteurized milk because pasteurization is a human-made process
column2: implying that natural processes are inherently better. This reasoning falls under the appeal to nature fallacy
column3: which assumes that what is natural is automatically good or preferable. The argument overlooks the potential health risks associated with consuming raw milk
column4: demonstrating that the belief in the superiority of natural products is not always justified."

column1: "What kind of sentence is this?

column1: "What do these two changes have in common?

column1: In a physical change

column1: "Complete the statement.

column2: 'a compound']	0	Zinc is a metal that is used to make batteries and musical instruments. The chemical formula for zinc is Zn.	closed choice	grade5	natural science	chemistry	Atoms and molecules	Classify elementary substances and compounds using chemical formulas	"Every substance around you is made of one or more chemical elements
column3: or types of atoms. Substances that are made of only one chemical element are elementary substances. Substances that are made of two or more chemical elements bonded together are compounds.

column1: Every chemical element is represented by its own symbol. For some elements
column2: the symbol is one capital letter. For other elements
column3: the symbol is one capital letter and one lowercase letter. For example
column4: the symbol for the element fluorine is F
column5: and the symbol for the element beryllium is Be.

column1: The symbol for each element in a substance is shown in the substance's chemical formula.
An elementary substance is represented by a chemical formula that contains only one symbol.

The symbol may be followed by a subscript. A subscript is text that is smaller and placed lower than the normal line of text. A subscript is included when the atoms in the elementary substance are bonded to form molecules. The subscript tells you the number of atoms in each molecule.
For example
column2: the chemical formula for the elementary substance oxygen is O2. The formula has a subscript of 2. This subscript tells you that there are two atoms in the molecule represented by this chemical formula.

column1: The chemical element represented by the symbol O is also called oxygen. So
column2: the formula O2 tells you that each molecule of O2 contains two oxygen atoms.

column1: A compound is represented by a chemical formula that contains multiple symbols.
For example
column2: in the compound beryllium fluoride
column3: there is one beryllium atom for every two fluorine atoms. This combination is shown in the compound's chemical formula
column4: BeF2. In the formula
column5: the symbol Be represents one beryllium atom. The symbol F followed by the subscript 2 represents two fluorine atoms."	"You can tell whether zinc is an elementary substance or a compound by counting the number of symbols in its chemical formula. A symbol contains either one capital letter or a capital letter followed by one or two lowercase letters.

column1: The chemical formula for zinc is Zn. This formula contains one symbol: Zn. So
column2: the formula tells you that zinc is made of one chemical element.

column1: Substances made of only one chemical element are elementary substances. So
column2: zinc is an elementary substance."	"ANSWER: 0

column1: SOLUTION: Zinc is classified as an elementary substance because its chemical formula
column2: Zn
column3: consists of only one symbol representing a single chemical element. Unlike compounds
column4: which are made up of two or more different elements
column5: zinc stands alone as a pure element. Therefore
column6: it does not combine with other substances in its basic form
column7: affirming that it is an elementary substance rather than a compound."
